awd_titl_txt: RAPID proposal: Impact of storm surge on coastal forest demography in response to repeated hurricane disturbances
awd_abstract_narration:
Large infrequent disturbances, such as hurricanes, significantly alter coastal forests through damaging winds and salt water carried with the storm surge. Depending on the frequency of the hurricanes and concurrent extent of the wind damage and salt water intrusion, coastal forests can be significantly damaged and may transition into salt water marsh. With a more variable climate system, hurricane return times will decrease and projected increasing sea level rise will enhance the opportunity for salt intrusion. Current understanding of hurricane effects is based largely on the effects of a single hurricane; few studies exist that document effects of repeated storms in one location or that separate the effects of storm surge from wind. In October 2016 Hurricane Matthew hit the South Carolina coast in largely in the same area affected by Hurricane Hugo in 1989, thus providing an opportunity to study multiple hurricane impacts on the same coastal forests. Hurricane Matthew differed in intensity and areas inundated with salt water. The project will introduce newer remote sensing capabilities to expand the studies to understand the short term and long term impacts on structure and functioning of the affected forests and at larger landscape and regional scales. This project's timely field assessments of wind damage, salt stress, soil chemistry, tree functioning, and tree establishment coupled with the remote sensing will test theoretical predictions and advance understanding of large infrequent disturbances on coastal forests. 

Large infrequent disturbances may structure forest ecosystem responses for very long periods of time and may trigger threshold responses that cause multiple paths of ecosystem response or even shifts in complete ecosystem structure and function. Much of the theory devoted to hurricane disturbance effects on coastal forest ecosystems arises from the study of single hurricanes or immediate response following the hurricane. Empirical tests and data are needed to evaluate multiple hurricanes across short and long time and site to regional space scales to fully understand the recovery and trajectories of change. This project leverages data and research sites from a long-term field study of coastal ecosystems to examine the consequences of the Hurricane Hugo on the recovery from wind throw and salt stress. The new studies will examine how wind damage and the salt intrusion from Hurricane Matthew affected soil processes, forest mortality and succession, forest functioning, and invasion of non-native species in response to differential hurricane disturbance. The remote sensing will assess forest structure, stress, phenology, and plant traits across the marsh/forest landscape and at multiple study areas along the coast of South Carolina. This work will provide critical tests of disturbance theory, succession, ecosystem structure and function across multiple space and time scales.

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of our project was to study the effects of Hurricane Matthew on a coastal forest in South Carolina to increase our knowledge on how hurricanes impact natural resources and shape the coastline.  As a one-year RAPID project, the primary objective was to quickly collect datasets in response to the hurricane that would give us a unique opportunity to study the effect of hurricanes, and particularly storm surge, on coastal forests.  Studying the response of coastal forests to hurricanes is important for several reasons:

  1. Coastal forests are valuable ecosystems because they:
    1. provide habitat to rare and endangered species
    2. provide services to other coastal ecosystems, like estuaries and salt marshes that are critical hotspots of biodiversity and home to valuable fisheries
    3. protect humans and infrastructure by buffering tropical storms
    4. provide jobs and economic benefits as part of forest industry
  2. However, these ecosystems experience many pressures, including:
    1. sea level rise
    2. intensifying tropical storms
    3. urban expansion and development

A very unique aspect of our project was that the eye of Hurricane Matthew passed directly over Hobcaw Barony, where Clemson University’s Baruch Institute of Coastal Ecology and Forest Science is located, and has maintained long-term forest research plots to study the effects of Hurricane Hugo, which devastated local forests in 1989. The impact of Hurricane Matthew on these plots 27 years later provided an excellent opportunity to study the effects of multiple hurricanes on forest ecology.

This project primarily supported field data collection and laboratory analyses during the one year grant period. The major datasets collected include: A) a GPS survey of the storm surge extent into the forest to identify the areas that were inundated by salt water, B) periodic measures of soil salinity along transects from the marsh, across the surge line in the forest to track the attenuation of soil salinity over time and confirm the location salt water inundation, C) a forest vegetation survey to determine year-1 forest mortality by species and size class in long-term Hugo-recovery plots, and D) unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) repeat multispectral photography to track forest stress and mortality with time after the hurricane.

Some specific outcomes include:

  • Increased understanding of the role of storm surge and mesoscale topography on the extent and location of forest mortality and potentially marsh expansion
  • Trained young scientists to use technology like UAVs and the software required to process the spatial datasets they produce, and in classical ecological methods in forestry and soils, including two undergraduates and two high school students (two male, two female). These students have or will also present work related to this project to the public, building their science communication skills.
  • This project employed and trained a recent female college graduate, who then transitioned to a permanent research technician position, thus aiding her professional developement.
  • Datasets (to be shared publicly) of high-resolution UAV remote sensing of marsh-forest boundary during period of recovery after Hurricane Matthew with soil salinity transects during the same period.
  • New technical capacity at the Baruch Institute to use UAVs in applications of coastal ecology.
  • Primary results of this research have been presented in two public events and one state-wide radio program: 2017 Clemson Baruch Institute “Behind the Gate” research, and 2018 Clemson Baruch 50th Anniversary seminar series and an SC Public Radio (NPR) piece. These are all public events and help our local community understand the effects of hurricanes and saltwater intrusion, while also continuing to explain the importance of scientific research.  Results have also been presented at two scientific conferences.  Journal manuscripts detailing results for the scientific community are forthcoming.
